prompt: <description>**Part 1: Three-Dimensional Rectangular Prism with a Flat Top and Bottom** Begin by creating a new coordinate system with euler angles 0.0, 0.0, 0.0 and translation vector 0.0, 0.0, 0.0. For the sketch, create a new face (face\\_1). On face\\_1, create loop\\_1 consisting of the following lines: - Line\\_1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.0] - Line\\_2: Start Point [0.75, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.7273] - Line\\_3: Start Point [0.75, 0.7273], End Point [0.0, 0.7273] - Line\\_4: Start Point [0.0, 0.7273], End Point [0.0, 0.0] Ensure that loop\\_1 is closed. Proceed to extrude the sketch along the normal by 0.0227 units, and zero depth in the opposite direction. Apply the given sketch scaling factor of 0.75. The expected part dimensions are as follows: - Shape: A three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. - Length: 0.75 units - Width: 0.75 units - Height: 0.0227 units **Additional Information on the CAD Assembly JSON**: This JSON structure provides the necessary steps to generate a CAD model assembly with a series of intermediate CAD parts. - The process for generating each intermediate CAD part follows four primary steps: 1. Establishing the coordinate system with euler angles and a translation vector. 2. Defining a 2D sketch based on the provided loops and faces. 3. Transforming the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using euler angles and a translation vector. 4. Extruding or adding complexity to the 2D sketch to create a 3D model using given parameters. Each CAD part has key components and properties, including coordinate system, sketch, extrusion, and description information. - The coordinate system defines the 3D rotation and translation of the 2D sketch plane. - The sketch consists of faces, loops, and one or more curves such as lines, arcs, and circles. - The extrusion applies depth and scaling to the 3D model based on given parameters. - The description offers additional information about the CAD part, such as its shape, length, width, and height. In the subsequent tasks, provide detailed step-by-step natural language instructions for the remaining parts, assemble interconnected CAD parts while adhering to specific boolean operations to create the final CAD model.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Construct a rectangular prism with a cylindrical hole in the center. The first part is a rectangular prism with a cylindrical hole in the center. The overall dimensions of the prism are 0.75 units in length, width, and height. Begin by creating a new coordinate system for this part. The euler angles for this coordinate system are all set to 0 degrees and the translation vector is at the origin (0, 0, 0). Next, create the 2D sketch for the first part. This sketch will be drawn on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system defined earlier. The sketch consists of three faces, where each face consists of multiple loops. 1. Face 1: Face 1 consists of three loops: loop 1, loop 2, and loop 3. Loop 1: Loop 1 is the outer boundary shape of Face 1. It starts with an arc, arc_1, with a start point (0, 0.05), a midpoint (0.0146, 0.0146), and an end point (0.05, 0) (Note that the arc is oriented counterclockwise). This is followed by line_1, which connects the end point of arc_1 to the point (0.7, 0), and then by arc_2, which connects (0.7, 0) to (0.75, 0.05). The arc_2 also has a start point (0.7, 0), a midpoint (0.7354, 0.0146), and an end point (0.75, 0.05) (Note that arc_2 is also oriented counterclockwise). Subsequently, line_2 connects (0.75, 0.05) to (0.75, 0.1) and is followed by arc_3, which connects (0.75, 0.1) to (0.7, 0.15). The arc_3 has a start point (0.75, 0.1), a midpoint (0.7354, 0.1354), and an end point (0.7, 0.15) (Note that arc_3 is oriented clockwise). Finally, line_3 connects (0.7, 0.15) to (0.05, 0.15), and arc_4 connects (0.05, 0.15) to (0, 0.1) (Note that arc_4 is oriented clockwise again), and finally line_4 connects (0, 0.1) to the starting point (0, 0.05) of arc_1 thereby closing the loop. Loop 2 and Loop 3: Both loop 2 and loop 3 are circles with a center at (0.1, 0.075) and (0.65, 0.075) respectively and with a radius of 0.025 each. Once the 2D sketch is complete, scale it by a factor of 0.75, and then transform it into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector information given by the coordinate system. Afterwards, extrude the 3D sketch along the normal direction to a depth of 0.1 units. This will result in the first part of the CAD model for this assembly.</description>
